questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 0, para 0, comes to the physician with her husband because of difficulty in having sexual intercourse. They have initially attempted to engage in intercourse at least twice a week after they got married 6 months ago, but are now only attempting intercourse every other week. During attempted vaginal penetration, the patient has discomfort and her pelvic floor muscles tighten up. The husband reports that recently he has had difficulties maintaining an erection during sexual activity, which he attributes to “not trying to hurt her.” Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and usually last 5 days with heavy flow. Three years ago, the patient was diagnosed with body dysmorphic disorder for which she undergoes cognitive behavioral therapy. There is no family history of serious illness. She does not smoke or drink alcohol and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a normal-appearing vulva without redness or tenderness; there is no vaginal discharge. An initial attempt at speculum examination is aborted after the patient's pelvic floor muscles tense up and she experiences discomfort. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Women affected by vulvodynia experience soreness and burning of the vulva that may be present continuously or triggered by touch or pressure (e.g., sexual intercourse, tampon use). The combination of discomfort and tightening of pelvic floor muscles on penetration experienced by this patient is not consistent with vulvodynia.

B) INCORRECT:

Inadequate vaginal lubrication can have a number of reasons, including female sexual arousal disorder, hormonal changes (e.g., menopause), nerve injury (e.g., multiple sclerosis, diabetic peripheral neuropathy), and medication intake (e.g., selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors). This patient's examination findings indicate that the vaginal discomfort and pelvic floor tightening are independent of possible discomfort secondary to dryness and inadequate lubrication. This patient's outer genital examination also does not indicate any signs of dryness or irritation, which are common if inadequate vaginal secretion is present. Additionally, she has neither associated features of sexual arousal disorder (e.g., no absent interest or participation in sexual activity) nor a history of illness or medication intake.

C) INCORRECT:

While most types of vulvovaginitis manifest with soreness, dryness, and a burning sensation, particularly following sexual intercourse, infectious vulvovaginitis shows further features like vaginal discharge or odor. Since this patient has neither a history of infection (e.g., vaginal discharge) nor complaints of vaginal dryness or pruritus, this diagnosis can be ruled out.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with bladder pain syndrome experience suprapubic pain or discomfort that is relieved by voiding as well as urinary urgency and frequency over a period of at least 6 weeks. While the suprapubic pain may be exacerbated by sexual activity, painful bladder syndrome does not impede penetration and can be ruled out in a patient without urinary symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms are suggestive of genito-pelvic pain/penetration disorder, a psychosexual condition that is characterized by persistent or recurrent difficulties during sexual intercourse. Characteristic symptoms include difficulty with vaginal penetration, vulvovaginal or pelvic pain during intercourse, anticipatory anxiety, and pronounced tightening of the pelvic floor muscles (historically referred to as vaginismus) during attempted vaginal penetration. The disorder often manifests in individuals with relationship issues (e.g., sexual problems also present in the partner), poor body image (e.g., body dysmorphic disorder), and psychiatric disorders (e.g., depression, anxiety).

F) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis manifests with dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and infertility. Although dyspareunia upon deep penetration is another possible symptom, vaginal discomfort upon attempted penetration is not expected. Furthermore, in a patient without recurrent pelvic pain, endometriosis is unlikely.
questions.hint: Pelvic floor physical therapy is an important part of the management of this condition.

questions.text: A previously healthy 20-year-old woman comes to her physician because of pain during sexual intercourse. She recently became sexually active with her boyfriend. She has had no other sexual partners. She is frustrated because she has consistently been experiencing severe, sharp vaginal pain on penetration. She has tried lubricants without significant relief. She has not been able to use tampons in the past due to similar pain with tampon insertion. External vulvar examination shows no abnormalities. She is unable to undergo a bimanual or speculum examination due to tightening of the pelvic floor muscles and pain with attempted digit or speculum insertion. Testing for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae is negative. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pelvic floor physical therapy is recommended for patients with genito-pelvic pain disorder, which is often associated with increased pelvic floor muscle tension. Components of physical therapy such as patient education, internal manual techniques, dilatation exercises, local tissue desensitization, and home exercises (e.g., Kegel exercises) have been shown to improve vaginal muscle mobility and help patients overcome vaginal penetration anxiety.

B) INCORRECT:

Vaginal botulinum toxin injections may help decrease the hypertonicity of the pelvic floor muscles but are not routinely recommended in patients with genito-pelvic pain disorder. Another noninvasive treatment option is more appropriate at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Cognitive behavioral interventions (e.g., sex therapy, couple-based therapy) focused on sexual pain and its impact on sexual function can be part of the management of genito-pelvic pain disorder, particularly in patients who have developed anxiety or a decrease in desire due to painful intercourse. While this patient has dyspareunia, she expresses frustration rather than anxiety. A different primary treatment directly addressing her pain is indicated at this point.

D) INCORRECT:

Lorazepam can help decrease anxiety, which may be caused by dyspareunia. However, this patient does not currently present with anxiety, and lorazepam is not routinely recommended in patients with genito-pelvic pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Vaginal estrogen cream is effective in alleviating symptoms caused by atrophic vaginitis, which can also manifest with painful penetration. However, atrophic vaginitis typically affects postmenopausal women and is an unlikely cause of this patient's dyspareunia.
questions.hint: Sharp vaginal pain on attempted penetration (e.g., sexual intercourse, tampon insertion) in an otherwise healthy young woman suggests genito-pelvic pain disorder.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulties achieving an erection for the past year. A medication is prescribed that inhibits cyclic GMP phosphodiesterase type 5. Which of the following is the most likely site of action of the prescribed drug?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

PDE-5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil) are commonly used to treat erectile dysfunction. Under normal circumstances, nitric oxide binds to guanylate cyclase and increases levels of cGMP, a nucleotide that causes smooth muscle relaxation. PDE-5 degrades cGMP, terminating this vasodilatory effect. By preventing the breakdown of cGMP, PDE-5 inhibitors cause smooth muscle relaxation in the penis and increased blood flow to the corpus cavernosum.

PDE-5 inhibitors can also be used to decrease pulmonary vascular resistance in patients with pulmonary hypertension.
Image Description:

Exogenous nitrous oxide (NO) activates guanylyl cyclase, resulting in activation of protein kinase G. There is a reduction in intracellular calcium as a result of increased sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase (SERCA) and an increase in myosin-light-chain-phosphatase (MLCP) activity, resulting in smooth muscle relaxation. The net result of both pathways is vasodilation.

B) INCORRECT:

The prostate produces and secretes important enzymes that contribute to seminal fluid and sperm function. The coordinated contraction of smooth muscle cells surrounding the prostatic urethra and ejaculatory ducts is essential for normal ejaculation. PDE-5 inhibitors cause smooth muscle relaxation to strengthen and prolong erections, but the prostate smooth muscle is not the target of these medications.

C) INCORRECT:

The corpus spongiosum is a sponge-like tissue on the ventral aspect of the penis that surrounds the penile urethra. The corpus spongiosum remains flaccid during an erection, preventing the urethra from collapsing and allowing the ejaculate to pass through the urethra without obstruction. PDE-5 inhibitors do not act on the corpus spongiosum.

D) INCORRECT:

The pelvic splanchnic nerves provide parasympathetic innervation to the genitals and pelvis and are also important in development of an erection. Signaling from the pelvic splanchnic nerves to the penis regulates vasodilation and increases blood flow in the penis, leading to an erection. However, PDE-5 inhibitors do not cause splanchnic nerve stimulation.

E) INCORRECT:

The pudendal nerve provides afferent sensory innervation to the perineum and external genitalia, as well as motor efferent innervation to the bulbospongiosus and ischiocavernosus muscles that are responsible for ejaculation. When stimulated, the pudendal nerve transmits sensory stimuli from the genitals to the parasympathetic nervous system, which leads to vasodilation and increased blood flow in the penis, causing an erection. However, PDE-5 inhibitors do not affect pudendal nerve signaling.
questions.hint: Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor that acts via smooth muscle cell relaxation and vasodilation.

questions.text: One day after undergoing surgery for a traumatic right pelvic fracture, a 73-year-old man has urinary incontinence and pain over his buttocks and scrotum. Physical examination shows right-sided perineal hypesthesia and absence of anal sphincter contraction when the skin around the anus is touched. This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional neurological deficits?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paralysis of hip adductors is seen in damage to the obturator nerve, which could be caused by hip or pelvic trauma. However, symptoms would include a sensory deficit on the medial surface of the anterior thigh. Right-sided perineal hypesthesia, absent anal sphincter contraction, and urinary incontinence would not be expected.

B) CORRECT:

The pudendal nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin of the perineum, external genitalia, and external urethral and anal sphincter muscles. A reflex erection occurs on tactile stimulation of the genital area, which stimulates the afferent fibers of the pudendal nerve. This activates a reflex arc with the parasympathetic nervous system at the sacral roots originating at S2 to S4, forwarding the stimulus to the inferior hypogastric plexus. This, in turn, leads to relaxation of the cavernous smooth muscle, which causes vasodilation (mediated by nitric oxide) and erection. The pudendal nerve may be injured in pelvic fractures or pelvic surgeries.

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired hip flexion would be consistent with damage to the femoral nerve (paralysis of iliopsoas, pectineus, rectus femoris, and sartorius muscles). The femoral nerve can also be damaged by pelvic trauma. However, it would manifest with further motor deficits, including impaired knee extension and a decreased patellar tendon reflex (paralysis of quadriceps femoris muscle). Additionally, sensory deficits of the anteromedial thigh (anterior cutaneous branches), medial lower leg, and medial edge of the foot (saphenous nerve lesion) would be expected instead of perineal hypesthesia, an absent sphincter reflex, and urinary incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

Psychogenic erection is caused by cortical stimulation with visual, aural, and sensory stimuli or fantasy, which activates the thoracolumbar erection center T11–L2 via fibers from the brain to the spine. These fibers can be damaged by spinal cord injury but are unlikely to be impaired by pelvic trauma or surgery. Furthermore, unilateral perineal hypesthesia, an absent sphincter reflex, and urinary incontinence would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

An absent cremasteric reflex can be seen in patients with damage to the ilioinguinal nerve (sensory innervation to the proximal medial aspect of the thigh) or the genitofemoral nerve (motor innervation to the cremaster muscle). However, damage to the ilioinguinal nerve results in sensory loss in the root of the penis and the anterior scrotum, and damage to the genitofemoral nerve results in decreased sensation to the anteromedial thigh, neither of which is seen here. In addition, right-sided perineal hypesthesia and absent anal sphincter contraction would not be expected.
questions.hint: The history of a recent pelvic trauma, symptoms of perineal hypesthesia, and pain in the pelvis and genitals, as well as an absent sphincter reflex and urinary incontinence, indicate a pudendal nerve injury.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician because of decreased sexual performance for the past 2 years. He reports that it takes longer for his penis to become erect, and he cannot maintain an erection for as long as before. His ejaculations have become less forceful. Once he has achieved an orgasm, he requires several hours before he can have another orgasm. He has been happily married for 40 years and he has no marital conflicts. His only medication is esomeprazole for gastroesophageal reflux disease. Examination shows coarse dark pubic and axillary hair. The skin of his lower extremity is warm to the touch; pedal pulses and sensation are intact. Rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged prostate with no masses. His fasting serum glucose is 96 mg/dL and his prostate-specific antigen is 3.9 ng/mL (N < 4). Which of the following etiologies is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction can be a manifestation of underlying vascular disease, often associated with conditions such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and peripheral artery disease. This patient's medical history and physical examination (warm lower extremities, intact pedal pulses and sensation) are not suggestive of a vascular etiology of his condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction can be caused by various classes of medications such as antihypertensives (e.g., beta-blockers, thiazide diuretics), antidepressants (e.g., SSRIs), and dopamine antagonists (e.g., antipsychotics). The patient is currently treated with esomeprazole, which is not associated with erectile dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Psychogenic erectile dysfunction may develop due to psychosocial stress (e.g., relationship trouble, trauma) or in association with an underlying psychiatric condition (e.g., depression, anxiety disorder). However, this patient does not report any marital conflicts nor does he demonstrate any symptoms of a psychiatric condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Prostate cancer is not a direct cause of erectile dysfunction, but treatment for this condition can lead to erectile dysfunction through the use of antiandrogen therapy or as a result of surgical excision. This patient's physical examination shows symmetrical growth of the prostate with no masses and normal prostate-specific antigen, which is consistent with benign prostatic hyperplasia.

E) INCORRECT:

Neurogenic causes of erectile dysfunction (ED) include stroke, trauma that affects the brain and/or spinal cord, and neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., multiple sclerosis, Parkinson disease), none of which are seen in this patient. Patients with neurogenic ED typically cannot develop erections. While this man is having difficulty obtaining and maintaining his erection, he is still able to develop an erection.

F) CORRECT:

Physiologic changes in male sexual function due to aging include delays in obtaining and maintaining an erection, longer refractory period between orgasms, and decreased ejaculate force and volume, which this patient describes. These are normal changes that progress gradually with advancing age, and they are not reflective of hormonal changes or decreased sexual desire.
questions.hint: Laboratory testing would reveal a normal testosterone level and decreased sperm production.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician because of concerns about his sexual performance for the past 3 years. The patient says that every time he sleeps with his life partner, within 30 seconds after penetration he has an orgasm which he cannot delay by any of the methods he has found on the internet. He has not had problems achieving an erection and cannot recall a triggering event for his concerns. Until now, he has never talked to a physician about his concerns because he feels embarrassed. He recently read in an article that approximately 1 in every 20 men experiences similar problems, which gave him the courage to come to the office today. He says that he cannot fully enjoy his sexual life and tries to avoid sexual intimacy although he feels attracted to his partner. He is happy with all other aspects of his relationship and personal life. He has hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Medications are chlorthalidone, losartan, and tamsulosin. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows no scrotal or penile abnormalities. In addition to recommending behavioral therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (PDE5 inhibitors) such as sildenafil can be used in patients with premature ejaculation who have concomitant erectile dysfunction. This patient has isolated premature ejaculation, for which sildenafil therapy is not indicated. Moreover, PDE5 inhibitors should be used with caution in patients who take alpha-receptor blockers, such as tamsulosin, because of a risk of orthostatic hypotension.

B) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin is a sympatholytic drug used for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Because of its sympatholytic properties, this drug can cause delayed ejaculation, as this process is stimulated by the sympathetic nervous system. Discontinuation is unlikely to provide any benefit to this patient with premature ejaculation.

C) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is a nonselective beta blocker that acts as a sympatholytic drug. Although ejaculation is primarily stimulated by the sympathetic nervous system, beta blockers do not play a role in the treatment of premature ejaculation. Beta blockers may cause erectile dysfunction, a different sexual disorder, and discontinuation of these drugs should be considered in patients with erectile dysfunction.

D) CORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as paroxetine, are used first-line but off-label for the treatment of premature ejaculation in patients without concomitant erectile dysfunction. The indication takes advantage of the side effect profile of SSRIs, which includes ejaculatory delay (up to 9 minutes for paroxetine) and orgasm disturbance. In addition to SSRIs, topical anesthetics (e.g., lidocaine-prilocaine spray) can be used to reduce the sensitivity of the penis and thereby decrease sexual stimulation. In addition to medical therapy, behavioral therapy can be offered to patients with significant psychological distress (e.g., lack of self-confidence, impaired life quality) and to those in whom psychogenic factors (e.g., anxiety, depression) play a role in the development of premature ejaculation.

In patients with concomitant erectile dysfunction, phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil, tadalafil) are used first-line because premature ejaculation is often an outcome of erectile dysfunction. Note that this drug class should be used with caution in patients who are treated with alpha-receptor blockers, such as tamsulosin, because of a risk of orthostatic hypotension.

E) INCORRECT:

Chlorthalidone is a thiazide diuretic that can cause erectile dysfunction. This patient has premature ejaculation without erectile dysfunction. Discontinuation of chlorthalidone is unlikely to provide any benefit to this patient.
questions.hint: This patient fulfills the diagnostic criteria for premature ejaculation in the absence of erectile dysfunction. The next step in management takes advantage of the side effect profile of a specific drug.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old patient presents to establish care. Although his sex was recorded as female at birth and he was raised in a female role, he reports identifying as a man and wishes to live as a man; his pronouns are he/him/his. This is the first transgender patient that you have provided care to.
The patient reports that growing up, he felt more like a boy than a girl. At the onset of puberty, he started developing depression with passive suicidal thoughts and engaged in deliberate self-harm at the onset of menses.
He is now requesting treatment for his gender incongruence.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Refer to a mental health professional
Refer to a breast surgeon for mastectomy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient is expressing gender incongruence, which is characterized by a marked and persistent incongruence between an individual’s experienced gender (their gender identity) and their assigned sex (the sex recorded at birth). The patient also appears to be experiencing gender dysphoria, which is a mental health diagnosis that refers to the distress or discomfort that individuals might feel when their gender identity is incongruent with the sex recorded at birth and the accompanying physical characteristics and associated gender roles.

Before any gender-affirming treatment (hormonal or surgical) is initiated, the patient’s gender identity should be fully evaluated, and the patient should be assessed for readiness to start medical therapy. This evaluation should be performed by someone who is experienced in the evaluation of patients with gender incongruence. For adult patients, this does not need to be a mental health professional but can be any experienced clinician, including a primary care provider, an endocrinologist, or another specialist.

Alternative explanations for this patient’s description of gender incongruence are few, and the other conditions being considered are usually easily distinguished from gender dysphoria. They include transvestism (cross-dressing), body dysmorphic disorder (persistent and intrusive belief that one’s appearance is defective), differences in sexual differentiation (intersex conditions that often manifest with ambiguous genitalia), and psychotic disorders with accompanying delusions.

Although the involvement of a mental health professional is not required before initiating gender-affirming care, these clinicians can be invaluable members of the treatment team. Their roles include:

• Evaluating the patient for any concurrent mental disorder, especially if there are symptoms such as self-harm and suicidal ideation (as in this case). Although identifying as transgender does not indicate the presence of a mental disorder, emotional and psychosocial concerns are common in this group (possibly due to adverse life experiences). Having reasonable control of any mental health concerns is one of the readiness criteria before gender-affirming treatment is initiated.
• Helping patients to explore gender identity in a supportive environment.
• Educating patients about options for gender-affirming care, including setting realistic expectations for the outcomes of hormonal, surgical, and other treatments.
• Planning for the change in gender role at home, in the workplace, and in society at large.
• Providing family support.
• Referring for peer support.

Once gender incongruence has been confirmed by an experienced clinician, gender-affirming care can be provided. The exact interventions will depend on the patient’s goals and desires. They can range from simple reversible changes, such as taking on a new name, wearing different clothing, and adopting a new hairstyle, to initiation of hormone therapy, which will induce physical changes that make the patient’s appearance more congruent with their gender identity, all the way to surgical interventions that alter the appearance of secondary sexual characteristics or the genitalia.

Key learning point: Gender-affirming hormonal therapy should be initiated only after an experienced clinician confirms gender incongruence.

B) INCORRECT:

Initiation of antidepressant therapy is sometimes appropriate in gender diverse patients who have severe depression or suicidality. However, initiation of gender-affirming care has been shown to have dramatic effects on patients’ mood, so referral to confirm the diagnosis with a view toward starting gender-affirming therapy is a better option for this patient than antidepressant therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Mastectomy is premature in a patient who has not yet been evaluated by a clinician with experience in transgender care.

D) INCORRECT:

Testosterone therapy is premature in a patient who has not yet been evaluated by a clinician with experience in transgender care.

E) INCORRECT:

Measuring estradiol and testosterone levels is unlikely to be helpful, given that these levels are not altered based on one's gender identity unless exogenous hormones have been given.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old patient whose sex was recorded as female at birth presents to your clinic with a new concern for school avoidance. At the start of the visit, the patient requests that you use the pronouns he/him/his in your communications, as the parents have been doing for the past year. The parents report that the patient has enjoyed dressing as a boy and playing with stereotypically masculine toys since early childhood. They note that he becomes visibly upset when anyone refers to him as a girl. On examination, breast development is consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage 1), and there is no pubic hair.
You refer the patient to a mental health professional who confirms a diagnosis of gender incongruence.
What is the most appropriate next step in hormonal intervention to consider for this patient?

choices.text: Begin progesterone therapy after the patient reaches menarche
Initiate testosterone therapy when the patient reaches sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 2
Initiate gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist therapy when the patient reaches sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 2
Delay hormonal intervention until the patient reaches the legal age of majority
Initiate gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist therapy now

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If an individual with gender incongruence does not present for evaluation until after the onset of puberty, hormonal intervention may still be initiated. For transmasculine (female-to-male) individuals, GnRH agonist or progesterone therapy may be used to suppress menstrual cycles. In children with gender incongruence, pubertal blockade should be considered when the child reaches sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 2.

B) INCORRECT:

A gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist should be initiated when a child with confirmed gender incongruence reaches sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 2, followed by sex steroid hormones later in adolescence.

C) CORRECT:

Gender incongruence is characterized by a marked and persistent incongruence between an individual’s experienced gender (their gender identity) and their assigned sex (the sex recorded at birth). This patient also has gender dysphoria, which is a mental health diagnosis that can be made in patients who experience distress or impaired function for at least 6 months because of gender incongruence. Children and adolescents with gender dysphoria have extremely high rates of depression, anxiety, self-harming behaviors, and suicidality, often as a consequence of rejection by family members and friends, leading to feelings of isolation.

The Endocrine Society and the World Professional Association for Transgender Health (WPATH) recommend referring all children with gender incongruence to a mental health professional with expertise in this area before making the diagnosis and initiating any hormonal intervention.

Children are aware of gender identity from a very young age, and some will demonstrate nonconforming behaviors as toddlers. Most children do not continue these behaviors or continue to identify as transgender into adolescence, but those who do tend to experience tremendous distress during puberty. In fact, many clinicians consider worsening of gender dysphoria at the onset of puberty to be an important diagnostic tool to determine which patients require hormonal intervention.

The goals of hormonal intervention are two-fold:

• To prevent the development of unwanted secondary sex characteristics (those associated with the sex recorded at the patient’s birth)
• To promote the development of desired secondary sex characteristics (those associated with the patient’s gender identity)

To that end, a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist should be initiated when a child with confirmed gender incongruence reaches sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 2 (defined by breast bud formation or testicular enlargement), followed by sex steroid hormones later in adolescence. GnRH agonists will prevent the development of unwanted secondary sex characteristics and halt the progression of puberty while the child continues to explore their gender identity. The initiation of sex hormone therapy is individualized to the patient based on medical, psychological, and social factors. Patients may benefit from the comprehensive care provided by clinicians with expertise in gender incongruence.

Key learning point: In children with gender incongruence, pubertal blockade should be considered when the child reaches sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 2, to prevent the development of unwanted secondary sex characteristics.

D) INCORRECT:

Definitive gender-affirming surgery is typically delayed until a patient reaches the legal age of majority. However, hormonal interventions may be initiated at an earlier age.

E) INCORRECT:

A gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist should be initiated when a child with confirmed gender incongruence reaches sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 2. Initiating hormonal intervention before the onset of puberty results in unnecessary costs and does not allow the clinician to assess whether the patient’s gender dysphoria worsens with the onset of puberty.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the office because of concerns about his sexual performance for the past 3 years. The patient says that every time he sleeps with his life partner, within 30 seconds after penetration he has an orgasm which he cannot delay by any of the methods he has found on the internet. He has not had problems achieving an erection and cannot recall a triggering event for his concerns. He is happy with all other aspects of his relationship and personal life. He has hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Medications are chlorthalidone, losartan, and tamsulosin. Genitourinary examination shows no scrotal or penile abnormalities. In addition to recommending behavioral therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (PDE5 inhibitors) such as sildenafil can be used in patients with premature ejaculation who have concomitant erectile dysfunction. This patient has isolated premature ejaculation, for which sildenafil therapy is not indicated. Moreover, PDE5 inhibitors should be used with caution in patients who take alpha-receptor blockers, such as tamsulosin, because of a risk of orthostatic hypotension.

B) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin is a sympatholytic drug used for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Because of its sympatholytic properties, this drug can cause delayed ejaculation, as this process is stimulated by the sympathetic nervous system. Discontinuation is unlikely to provide any benefit to this patient with premature ejaculation.

C) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is a nonselective beta blocker that acts as a sympatholytic drug. Although ejaculation is primarily stimulated by the sympathetic nervous system, beta blockers do not play a role in the treatment of premature ejaculation. Beta blockers may cause erectile dysfunction, a different sexual disorder, and discontinuation of these drugs should be considered in patients with erectile dysfunction.

D) CORRECT:

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as paroxetine, are used first-line but off-label for the treatment of premature ejaculation in patients without concomitant erectile dysfunction. The indication takes advantage of the side effect profile of SSRIs, which includes ejaculatory delay (up to 9 minutes for paroxetine) and orgasm disturbance. In addition to SSRIs, topical anesthetics (e.g., lidocaine-prilocaine spray) can be used to reduce the sensitivity of the penis and thereby decrease sexual stimulation. In addition to medical therapy, behavioral therapy can be offered to patients with significant psychological distress (e.g., lack of self-confidence, impaired life quality) and to those in whom psychogenic factors (e.g., anxiety, depression) play a role in the development of premature ejaculation.

In patients with concomitant erectile dysfunction, phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil, tadalafil) are used first-line because premature ejaculation is often an outcome of erectile dysfunction. Note that this drug class should be used with caution in patients who are treated with alpha-receptor blockers, such as tamsulosin, because of a risk of orthostatic hypotension.

E) INCORRECT:

Chlorthalidone is a thiazide diuretic that can cause erectile dysfunction. This patient has premature ejaculation without erectile dysfunction. Discontinuation of chlorthalidone is unlikely to provide any benefit to this patient.
questions.hint: This patient fulfills the diagnostic criteria for premature ejaculation in the absence of erectile dysfunction. The next step in management takes advantage of the side effect profile of a specific drug.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man reports that he has felt depressed for the past 3 months. He awakens much earlier than usual, feeling fretful. He has low energy, poor concentration, and limited interest in his usual activities throughout the day. He also notes that since becoming depressed, he has had difficulty having sexual relations with his steady girlfriend, including decreased ability to obtain or maintain an erection and a decreased frequency of orgasms. Which one of the following treatment strategies is most appropriate to restore this patient’s erectile function?

choices.text: Refer to urology for intracavernous alprostadil

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sildenafil should not be considered for this patient at this point. If sexual dysfunction persists even after depression symptoms improve, a search for causes should be carried out before implementing any other treatment for sexual dysfunction.

B) INCORRECT:

Sex therapy should not be considered for this patient at this point. If sexual dysfunction persists even after depression symptoms improve, a search for causes should be carried out before implementing any other treatment for sexual dysfunction.

C) CORRECT:

Sexual dysfunction is likely a symptom of major depression in this young man, so treating the depression is the most appropriate first step. Bupropion is a good choice, because it is an effective antidepressant that does not typically cause sexual side effects or decreased libido. The antidepressant alone may solve the erectile dysfunction and the depression. Bupropion is the best choice among the options listed, but psychosocial treatment would also be appropriate in this setting, usually in the form of cognitive behavioral therapy. Such treatment requires an ongoing commitment from the patient and involves finding an appropriate therapist with whom the patient can build a relationship. If the patient will accept it, a combination of medication and psychotherapy is generally more effective than either treatment alone.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial treatment to restore erectile function in a patient with untreated major depressive disorder is an antidepressant with a low incidence of sexual side effects, such as bupropion.

D) INCORRECT:

Alprostadil should not be considered for this patient at this point. If sexual dysfunction persists even after depression symptoms improve, a search for causes should be carried out before implementing any other treatment for sexual dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Venlafaxine is an effective antidepressant but carries a higher risk for sexual side effects than bupropion.

questions.text: A 29-year-old patient presents to establish care. Although his sex was recorded as female at birth and he was raised in a female role, he reports identifying as a man and wishes to live as a man; his pronouns are he/him/his. This is the first transgender patient that you have provided care to. The patient reports that growing up, he felt more like a boy than a girl. At the onset of puberty, he started developing depression with passive suicidal thoughts and engaged in deliberate self-harm at the onset of menses. He is now requesting treatment for his gender incongruence. What is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Refer to a mental health professional
Refer to a breast surgeon for mastectomy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient is expressing gender incongruence, which is characterized by a marked and persistent incongruence between an individual’s experienced gender (their gender identity) and their assigned sex (the sex recorded at birth). The patient also appears to be experiencing gender dysphoria, which is a mental health diagnosis that refers to the distress or discomfort that individuals might feel when their gender identity is incongruent with the sex recorded at birth and the accompanying physical characteristics and associated gender roles.

Before any gender-affirming treatment (hormonal or surgical) is initiated, the patient’s gender identity should be fully evaluated, and the patient should be assessed for readiness to start medical therapy. This evaluation should be performed by someone who is experienced in the evaluation of patients with gender incongruence. For adult patients, this does not need to be a mental health professional but can be any experienced clinician, including a primary care provider, an endocrinologist, or another specialist.

Alternative explanations for this patient’s description of gender incongruence are few, and the other conditions being considered are usually easily distinguished from gender dysphoria. They include transvestism (cross-dressing), body dysmorphic disorder (persistent and intrusive belief that one’s appearance is defective), differences in sexual differentiation (intersex conditions that often manifest with ambiguous genitalia), and psychotic disorders with accompanying delusions.

Although the involvement of a mental health professional is not required before initiating gender-affirming care, these clinicians can be invaluable members of the treatment team. Their roles include:

• Evaluating the patient for any concurrent mental disorder, especially if there are symptoms such as self-harm and suicidal ideation (as in this case). Although identifying as transgender does not indicate the presence of a mental disorder, emotional and psychosocial concerns are common in this group (possibly due to adverse life experiences). Having reasonable control of any mental health concerns is one of the readiness criteria before gender-affirming treatment is initiated.
• Helping patients to explore gender identity in a supportive environment.
• Educating patients about options for gender-affirming care, including setting realistic expectations for the outcomes of hormonal, surgical, and other treatments.
• Planning for the change in gender role at home, in the workplace, and in society at large.
• Providing family support.
• Referring for peer support.

Once gender incongruence has been confirmed by an experienced clinician, gender-affirming care can be provided. The exact interventions will depend on the patient’s goals and desires. They can range from simple reversible changes, such as taking on a new name, wearing different clothing, and adopting a new hairstyle, to initiation of hormone therapy, which will induce physical changes that make the patient’s appearance more congruent with their gender identity, all the way to surgical interventions that alter the appearance of secondary sexual characteristics or the genitalia.

Key learning point: Gender-affirming hormonal therapy should be initiated only after an experienced clinician confirms gender incongruence.

B) INCORRECT:

Initiation of antidepressant therapy is sometimes appropriate in gender diverse patients who have severe depression or suicidality. However, initiation of gender-affirming care has been shown to have dramatic effects on patients’ mood, so referral to confirm the diagnosis with a view toward starting gender-affirming therapy is a better option for this patient than antidepressant therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Mastectomy is premature in a patient who has not yet been evaluated by a clinician with experience in transgender care.

D) INCORRECT:

Testosterone therapy is premature in a patient who has not yet been evaluated by a clinician with experience in transgender care.

E) INCORRECT:

Measuring estradiol and testosterone levels is unlikely to be helpful, given that these levels are not altered based on one's gender identity unless exogenous hormones have been given.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to your clinic reporting a 3-month history of feeling depressed. He describes waking up much earlier than usual, feeling anxious. He has low energy, poor concentration, and diminished interest in his usual activities throughout the day. He also reports that since becoming depressed, he has had difficulty with sexual activity with his steady girlfriend, including decreased ability to obtain or maintain an erection and reduced frequency of orgasms. Which one of the following treatment strategies is most appropriate to restore his erectile function?

choices.text: Refer to urology for intracavernous alprostadil.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sildenafil should not be considered for this patient at this point. If sexual dysfunction persists even after depression symptoms improve, a search for causes should be carried out before implementing any other treatment for sexual dysfunction.

B) INCORRECT:

Venlafaxine is an effective antidepressant but carries a higher risk for sexual side effects than bupropion.

C) INCORRECT:

Alprostadil should not be considered for this patient at this point. If sexual dysfunction persists even after depression symptoms improve, a search for causes should be carried out before implementing any other treatment for sexual dysfunction.

D) CORRECT:

Sexual dysfunction is likely a symptom of major depression in this young man, so treating the depression is the most appropriate first step. Bupropion is a good choice, because it is an effective antidepressant that does not typically cause sexual side effects or decreased libido. The antidepressant alone may solve the erectile dysfunction and the depression. Bupropion is the best choice among the options listed, but psychosocial treatment would also be appropriate in this setting, usually in the form of cognitive behavioral therapy. Such treatment requires an ongoing commitment from the patient and involves finding an appropriate therapist with whom the patient can build a relationship. If the patient will accept it, a combination of medication and psychotherapy is generally more effective than either treatment alone.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial treatment to restore erectile function in a patient with untreated major depressive disorder is an antidepressant with a low incidence of sexual side effects, such as bupropion.

E) INCORRECT:

Sex therapy should not be considered for this patient at this point. If sexual dysfunction persists even after depression symptoms improve, a search for causes should be carried out before implementing any other treatment for sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the clinic to discuss changes in his sexual function. He reports that over the past few years, it has become more difficult to achieve an erection, and his erections are not as firm. He is still sexually active with his wife and maintains a strong interest in intimacy. His medical history is significant for well-controlled hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. On examination, his blood pressure is 132/78 mm Hg. Secondary sexual characteristics are normal, and there is no testicular atrophy or penile plaques. Which of the following findings is most consistent with expected physiologic changes of aging?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Retrograde ejaculation, where semen enters the bladder instead of being expelled through the urethra, is not a normal physiologic change of aging. It is most commonly a side effect of medications, particularly alpha-blockers used for benign prostatic hyperplasia (e.g., tamsulosin), or a complication of prior prostate or bladder neck surgery. It can also result from neurologic conditions such as diabetes mellitus.

B) CORRECT:

A longer refractory period, the time required after ejaculation before another erection can be achieved, is one of the classic, normal physiologic changes of the male sexual response cycle associated with aging. Other expected changes include requiring more direct and intense stimulation to achieve an erection, erections that are less firm, decreased ejaculatory volume and force, and a reduced sensation of ejaculatory inevitability. This patient's report of less firm erections is also consistent with aging. Importantly, libido, or sexual interest, often remains intact, as described in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Acquired penile curvature during erection is the characteristic sign of Peyronie disease, a condition caused by the formation of fibrous scar tissue (plaques) in the tunica albuginea. This is a distinct pathologic process, not a normal consequence of aging. The physical examination finding of no penile plaques also makes this diagnosis less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

While the frequency and duration of nocturnal erections (nocturnal penile tumescence) naturally decrease with age, a complete absence is not a normal physiologic finding. The presence of nocturnal erections typically indicates intact neurovascular pathways. Their complete absence suggests an organic, rather than psychogenic, cause of erectile dysfunction and warrants further investigation for underlying vascular or neurologic disease.
questions.hint: Normal aging affects the timing and intensity of each phase of ejaculation.
